title: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, will an armed group from Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Sudan?
preds: EWP with bias to overestimate risk, projected risk of 10%
The Early Warning Project estimates this at about 10%, and one month of the year has passed.
Keeping it at 5 but see upward pressure. Omar popularity waning - without anyone else to blame he needs to keep delivering economic goods.

Right now, the answer is no, absolutely not. From January 1st of 2018 to January 1st of 2019, there was just under 300 [ACLED DATA] people killed by state forces (not filtered for the intent to kill, if filtered appropiately, the number would likely drop). The definition that we are under for genocide in this definition is there needs to be 1000 deaths from the state or more. So, as of right now, they don't have the numbers for this to happen.   However, in the last month, things seem to be changing. there has been a spike of riots and protests over the last month.  Against the current president of Sudan, Omar al-Bashir. So the question is, why would Bashir carry out a genocide now, and why has he not before? Well the answer is, to protect his position in the highest office in Sudan. And how many people have to be killed to protect his office or in the ruling party?  And how many institutions have to be toppled for the genocide to continue or happen.  Why are the people rioting now? Because of food shortages? Why is there a food shortage? I'm not sure yet, I am still in class.  The people who are being killed on a larger scale, are happening in Central Darfur, which is not close to the Capital of Sudan.
Early Warning base rate is 9.7% No recent mention on Genocide Watch. ACLED civilian data for the last few years is single or low double digits per month. Low chance.
Much of this depends on the stability of Sudan now that political resistance has formed inside Sudan.
Gov't will put down ongoing protests
I don't really have much faith in my prediction, but history doesn't encourage optimism.
I assume this includes South Sudan If not probability drops to 5%
many of the groups are large enough to inflict this kind of damage.
it depends on Sudan's economy and if Israel and the US can find a better puppet
